Nanung Kingdom (, Nanun or Nanumba Kingdom) is one of the earliest known ancient states in Northern Ghana, with Bimbilla as its capital and the Bimbilla Naa as the Overlord or King.Nanuŋ is located in the Eastern Corridor of Ghana, mainly in the Northern Region and parts of the Oti Region.
History
Nanung Kingdom was founded by Naa Gmantambu (), a son of Naa Gbewaa, in the 13th century after migrating south from his brother Naa Sitobu, who founded the present-day Dagbon Kingdom. The new state was subsequently called Nanung, which came from the Dagbani words "Naa" (King or Chief) and "Nua" (Hand). Naa Sitobu is said to have pointed his hand south, and Naa Gmantambu and his followers went in the direction indicated by the hand. So "Naa Nua" (The King's hand) became Nanung.
Royal Houses
The 'Skin' () is the symbol of authority in Nanung (also called Naam), just as it is in most traditional states in Northern Ghana. Nanuŋ has two royal families that ascend to the Bimbilla Naam in an alternating arrangement. These royal families include Gbuhmayili () and Bangyili ().The princes and princesses from these two royal families are also primarily appointed as chiefs and queens in most towns and villages of Nanung.
Geography
Nanung Kingdom stretches along the Eastern Corridor, covering districts including Nanumba North Municipality, Nanumba South, and major parts of Nkwanta North. Major towns in Nanung include Lepusi (), Bincheratanga, Bakpaba, Dimong, Pusiga, Bimbilla, Nakpayili, Wulensi (), Lungni, Chichahi, Chamba, Taali, Dokpam, Opijua, Nakpayili, Puduya, Binda, Kpassa, Oti-Damanko and Sibi.
Demography, Ethnicity and Chieftancy
Nanung is a multi-ethnic kingdom, with Nanumbas, direct siblings and sworn brothers to both Dagombas and Mamprusi as the main ruling tribe. Nanumbas are also direct cousin to Mossi people () of the Mossi Kingdoms of Burkina Faso. Konkombas are the other major tribe of the Kingdom. Other minority tribes include Chambas, Chokosi, Tem (also known as the Temba or Kotokoli), Ewes, Bassaris, Nawuris, and a host of other smaller tribes.
In recent decades, the Nanumba Traditional Council, which Ghana's constitution recognizes as the paramount governing council of Nanung, has relaxed its strict rules regarding chieftaincy, which was previously reserved exclusively for Nanumbas. Now, individuals from minority tribes are appointed as chiefs under specific circumstances and with the approval of the Bimbilla Naa, who also serves as the president of the council. This change has contributed to improved harmony and peaceful coexistence within the kingdom.

The succession line in Nanung follows a patrilineal system. Consequently, all future Kings are considered direct descendants of Naa Gmantambu (the founding King) and, by extension, Naa Gbewaa.
Struggle Against Colonialism
In late 1896, Nanung became the first traditional kingdom to engage the invading German colonial army in an open and direct war. The resistance was led by Naa Abalsi, the reigning king of Nanung. Under the command of Lieutenant Valentin von Massow, the German army reached Bimbilla on November 29, 1896, effectively occupying the kingdom. The occupation of Bimbilla was generally seen as a precursor to the Battle of Adibo against the Dagomba army.
Festivals
The main festivals in Nanung Inludes Damba festival, Fire festival (), Eid al-Fitr (), Eid al-Adha (), and Guineafowl festival ().
Economy
Yam farming is the primary occupation of the people in Nanung. In addition to yams, maize, rice, and soybeans are also cultivated in the region. Together, these crops contribute to making Nanung one of the main breadbaskets of Ghana. The thriving agricultural sector has led to the development of significant markets in the area, including Bimbilla Market, Chemba Market, Kpassa Market, Nakpayili Market, and Bincheratanga.
Famous Landmarks
The Oti and Daka rivers, international water bodies in West Africa, flow through much of Nanung. Towns such as Chihahi, Kukuo, Opijua, and Oti-Damanko are all situated along these rivers. The rivers' presence also supports other economic activities like fishing and ferrying.
The  Eastern Corridor Road, officially the National Highway 2 (N2), is a major national highway stretching from Accra to Northern Ghana. The road links the Kingdom to Nkwanta and Hohoe in the South, and Yendi and Tamale in the North. In Nanung, the road passes through the centre of major towns including Sibi, Kpassa, Oti-Damanko, Opijua, Bimbilla, Bincheratanga, Bakpaba, and Lepusi.
Naa Gmantambu Palace, the royal palace of the Bimbilla Naa, located in Bimbilla, is a major symbol of culture and heritage. It hosts all major festivals. The Overlord also appears at the palace court every Friday to receive homage from subjects and sub-chiefs across the Kingdom.
Bimbilla Market, one of the largest grain and yam tuber markets in Northern Ghana, is located in Bimbilla. Smaller markets with similar agricultural produce are found in towns and villages throughout Nanung. The markets in Nanung serve more than just a trading purpose; they are also venues for entertainment. On market days, visitors can enjoy cultural drumming and dancing, along with a variety of local dishes and beverages. Market days typically occur on a rotational weekly schedule.
[https://epcoebimbilla.edu.gh/ Bimbico], one of the oldest public teacher training universities in Ghana, is located in Bimbilla. It was established in 1962 by the Evangelical Presbyterian Church. It's now called E. P. College of Education, Bimbilla and runs four-year Bachelor of Education degree programs.
